author: Person
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2019
review_content: Bought this game for our family vacation. Had high ratings and awards and said for ages 8+. I have an 8, 11 and 13 yo and parental guidance is strongly suggested. Was surprised by some of the cards included in this game, especially since the game website says for 6 and up, and the ages of the kids pictured in the description. Most cards are funny and potty humor but I‚Äôd still not feel comfortable letting my 13 yo play alone with his friends without removing several cards from the deck.On the other hand, my husband and I found the game fun. Lots of old school references and not as raunchy as CAH.
title: Funny, but not appropriate for stated age.

author: Roberta
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2018
review_content: As a grand parent I did not realize the potty talk these cards would produce.  Over 75% of the cards used sexual/potty language.  I had looked at the top few reviews and thought this would be a great game for my 8 and 10 year old grand children.  I was rather shocked at the language on the cards.  I know I am of a different generation but I would not buy this game again even for older teens.
title: I am of a different generation

author: Chris
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 8, 2019
review_content: If you have any sort of humor in your blood, this is the family game for you. We ordered this game before we left for spring break so we could play when we needed a break from the beach/pool. It did not disappoint in the least. My kids, along with my nieces and nephews (ranging from 6-16) were laughing uncontrollably the entire time. The phrase possibilities are as creative and funny as you can make them. I think my 8 year old had the best time. He literally said the next morning after our first night of playing that his stomach was sore. If you‚Äôre one of those parents who get offended easy...you should definitely get this game and learn to loosen up a bit. We need to be able to laugh especially nowadays. And if we can‚Äôt do that with our kids, then who can you do that with. Great game and will be recommending it to all of my friends.
title: One word...Hilarious!

author: Jessica T.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2019
review_content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video.          ¬†I bought this game as a family game for my boys. We are a family of five, with the oldest who is 15 and the youngest is 6 years old. All of us find it very entertaining, even us adults. The game is stimulating and we always find words combinations that are silly and funny. My main concern was the level of appropriateness. I simply remove some cards based on the crowd playing with the game. We adults enjoy it too. One of my sons are very shy by nature and seeing him come out of his shell as he is playing with his friend, makes it worth it. As a mom, seeing your family laughing and interacting with one another is priceless!
title: Interactive game for kids of all ages!

author: Mother_of_5
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 15, 2019
review_content: My family‚Äôs favorite game to play. We have family game night once a week and this is always the one everyone wants to play. Our kids are 12, 10 & 8. It‚Äôs great to hear everyone laughing and having a great time while playing it. There was a few (less than 5) cards my husband and I took out before we played it with our kids. They need to make expansion packs.
title: My family‚Äôs favorite game.

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2019
review_content: This game was purchased for my family with children ages 8 and up but after playing with my friend's 14 year old daughter, my kids wont be playing this.  Answers like Aunt Flo, The Gooch, and Neverland Ranch are not appropriate and open up discussions that don't need to be had at such young ages.  Also one round read "King Kong played Ping Pong with his (Ding Dong) in Hong Kong."  Again not really appropriate for kids.  For being a kids game answers like Electric Slide have no meaning to them and while I know "poop" jokes are funny to kids there are way too many of them in this game.
title: Not appropriate for younger kids.

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 19, 2018
review_content: Great game! Perfect balance between apples to apples and cards against humanity. The 1 star review that was left about it‚Äôs content I couldn‚Äôt agree less with, it‚Äôs mentioned on the description that it has innuendos in the game, and honestly any cartoon on tv today has the same, get with times old lady. We‚Äôve played this with family and friends from ages 7-72 and had a blast every time. Nothing offensive. Cannot wait to play with the extended family at Christmas. 5 star! This is the second set I‚Äôve bought (Santa‚Äôs coming)

review_content: We love this game! This is a real crowd pleaser. We hosted a family game night with friends and their kids and we all had a great time. Kids like the silly cards and the adult humor is totally lost on them. Highly recommend this game!

author: Christy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2018
review_content: Just opened the game to play.....and some cards we cant use. Will update after we play the game on how we like it. So just got done playing and I had to take all these white cards out. My kids are 13 and 10 and while they know what some things are these are just not appropriate in my opinion. I'm a pretty easy going person and mom but 'plump pageant moms' 'the gooch' and 'a fat lady in yoga pants' is just teaching kids it's ok to make fun of someone. We had fun playing but I would highly suggest removing these cards from your game.

author: R. Siver
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2019
review_content: I have played Cards Against Humanity and have taken out all the inappropriate cards in order to play with my tweens. Kids Against Maturity is perfect for the whole family! date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2019
review_content: Brilliant!! I was recommended to get this game for my nieces this Christmas from a friend. We had so much fun playing with the entire family all weekend. I feel it is my duty to recommend it. The game is real deal laughs.

author: DW
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2019
review_content: marked as appropriate for ages 8+some of the answers are x rated - therefore explaining it to an 8 year old would violate federal law.ex: merkin wig, moose knuckle, spider barks, A-hole, Fromunda cheese, puckered starfish, Hershey highway, turd burglar (actually a derogatory statement insulting the LBGQT community), banana hammock, big brown beaver, and more...I'm fine (as an adult) with games like these), but it is NOT appropriate for an 8 year old.  getting a refund.
title: violates Federal law

author: Tammy L
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2020
review_content: So, I was hoping for a milder version of cards against humanity for our vacation rental (usually multigenerational family vacationers), and this def is ‚Äúmilder‚Äù.  There‚Äôs still A LOT of suggestive cards, and about a dozen ‚Äúmaybe not‚Äù cards that I separated and left in the box labeled (pictured).  I played the whole deck w my 15 yr old and showed it to my 16 yr old - even they were baffled at the ‚Äúage 8‚Äù recommendation - I def won‚Äôt play it w my 7 yr old and my husband won‚Äôt even consider the game.  There were a couple duplicates, as well.  Overall, it‚Äôs mostly potty humor and general things that will just sound funny when you put it with something else. But even after pulling out the dozen cards there‚Äôs still some on the gray line. Eg: ‚Äúwhere do babies come from‚Äù ended up with ‚Äúturkey baster‚Äù, ‚Äúthe circle of trust‚Äù and ‚Äúmom jeans‚Äù.  If you‚Äôre looking for a clean game for the family, this won‚Äôt be it.  I‚Äôd say age 10+, after pulling some raunchy inappropriate cards.  Every family is different though.  It satisfies the multigenerational game requirement though, and would say it‚Äôs good for ages 10-99 (if grandma and grandpa won‚Äôt mind it).
title: Still not for age 8

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2019
review_content: This game is very inappropriate for kids and teens. We played last night and it only took a few rounds for our boys to pull out the urban dictionary. "Mary plopkins" is one of the MANY cards, with double meaning. I would say it is worse then cards against humanity.

author: Shildy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 15, 2019
review_content: Played this with the neighbors (and an 11 year old) and we were mortified. I wouldn't give this to anyone younger than 18.  I am returning ASAP.

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2018
review_content: I really was happy to find a game that supposedly my kids could play. But upon getting this out and hearing my children playing this game with their uncle......umm....yeah...the underlying adult innuendoes are dominant. My brother in law was laughing his butt off but my children had no idea why. I have to admit I was listening to all of this and was laughing at them playing this game but my children will not be playing this again. The adults played later that night and it was gut busting fun for us. I read the back of the box and honestly this is my error not the game because it says right there on the back of the box, "Layered innuendoes for parents and kids to enjoy equal levels of laughter." So, for the game itself, awesome fun. But for kids, I would say no.
title: Not Necessarily Kid Friendly

author: Prettysmartideas
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2019
review_content: Okay, I was looking for something I might be able to use in an ESL class.  This is definitely not it.  Too much body excretion, not much else. I don't even know anyone who would like to have something like this. Oh well. Maybe you and your kids are into this kind of business.

author: Sara

review_content: The amount of cards and quality is great,  on par with the original CAH. The age rating of 8+ however is inaccurate. author: Minnesota CB

review_content: ...but if you're looking for a game that is appropriate for kids and adults to play together, this is NOT it.  I  bought if to play as a family over the holidays. review_content: I'm writing this review because I feel a lot of the 5 star reviews on this game are misleading. My children have great humor, but are also modest and would be embarrassed to play this with the adults in their lives. As I went through the cards, as suggested, to weed them out I was pulling too many. This will go to Goodwill. I just can't subject my kids to some of these phrases.  I've included a photo so reviewers can see what they're ordering.I was optimistic about this game as we really love Apples to Apples and hoped this would be similar, but ultimately it was a waste of money for us.

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2018
review_content: I bought this for my three daughters one is 10 the other is 14 and the last one is 16. My ten year old loved it and it is a great game for her and her friends. She is a little mature for her age however and depending on your kids level of maturity you may want to think about this game. Cards range from things like "dirty socks" too "magic mushrooms" so yes some cards are a little mature and this should be called preteens against maturity. My 14 year old thinks it is a little childish, but still enjoys playing it. She had asked for "Cards against Humanity" for Christmas and I personally thought that game is too much for a 14 year old. She enjoys this game and knows what all the cards mean. My 16 year old has no interest in this game. Like my 14 year old she had asked for "Cards Against Humanity". She plays the game but would much rather a more mature game. Do not buy this for a kid under ten or under 4th grade. If you have kids over 13-14 they probably won't enjoy this game! However it is a cleaner (not very clean though) alternative to "Cards against humanity"

review_content: There‚Äôs a lot more ‚Äútwig-and-berries‚Äù jokes than I‚Äôm comfortable with. author: Thomas D
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2018
review_content: There is enough slight innuendo for adults to play along with their kids. I have an 11 and 13 year old that think they are being so hilarious and offensive when they play this. Perfect for their age and had us laughing hysterically many times.

author: JaymeB
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2019
review_content: I was looking for a substitute for Cards Against Humanity for teens/family friendly play. There are two problems with this game - the question and answer cards are very disproportionate in terms of questions that need a noun in response and ones that need phrases. So this means that you end up throwing away cards and not really being able to play in a hand - we hand entire rounds like this where no one had a noun card to play. The second problem - the amount of bathroom humor. Don't get me wrong, I love bathroom humor as much as the next person, but the bathroom humor in this game just isn't funny. There are answer cards that have the word boogers or butt added into the answer, just for the sake of adding the word.So all in all, I think I'm back to where we started. Apples to apples is too young, cards against humanity is too old and my teens are stuck in the middle without a good game for their age group. Six to eight year old boys might find this game funny for a couple of minutes.
title: Not funny, too young for teens

author: Dollybantry
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2020
review_content: Our family owns and enjoys a lot of these Apples to Apples-style games, some we play with adults and some with the kids. Since we love Cards Against Humanity, we decided this family-friendly version might be a good idea. Not so much. The cards weren‚Äôt really that funny for the kids, and there‚Äôs way too much emphasis on bathroom humor, almost as if that‚Äôs the only thing the creators could imagine kids would find hilarious. After, like, the seventh poop joke in as many rounds, my kids were bored and, frankly, felt like their intelligence was being insulted. We all enjoy a similar game, Not Parent Approved, much more.
title: Not that funny and too much bathroom humor

author: Just Suz
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 8, 2020
review_content: Let me preface this by saying I LOVE Cards Against Humanity. And I LOVE playing Apples to Apples with my kids. But this game is NOT funny. It's just stupid. All the answer cards are things like "teaspoon full of toenail clippings" "banana hammock" and "jar full of egg farts." And the clue cards are things like "It's raining, it's pouring, ____ is snoring." There's nothing funny about it, the choices are just really stupid and completely irrelevant to the clue. My kids (10 and 13) hated it. We'll never play again. Is it returnable once opened?
title: I'm sure we'll never play this again

author: A. Alam

author: My2Cents
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 20, 2019
review_content: Played this with my 8 and 10 year old, and they loved it, what they understood of it anyway, and I get that poop jokes / fart jokes are what they think is funny these days, and that's fine. The product description did mention that. But there are more inappropriate cards in the deck, not mentioned, that I will be removing. I'm not explaining the sexual innuendos to them, obviously. I'd say this is more geared toward teens, not kids.
title: Not for Younger Children

author: McKenna Fleming
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2020
review_content: We had so much fun playing! We laughed until we cried!
title: Buy this!!!

author: sp
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2020
review_content: This card game was fun until the third sexual innuendos in the jokes. Even my 13 yr old grandson said. ‚ÄúAwkward‚Äù lol. During game. Too much  Seemingly written by a older person who is a bit much perverted. Not family friendly. Why go there.
title: SEXUAL INUENDOS. DONT BUY FOR KIDS.

author: Don
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 9, 2020
review_content: Wow. This game is dirty. I found it appropriate for adults having some drinks. Kids/ no way. I had to look up some of the terms on Urban Dictionary.  Learned some new R and X rated terms. Dirt button. Santa‚Äôs big fat sack. Front farts. Moose knuckle. Frodo‚Äôs ring finger. Bangkok. Lincoln‚Äôs log. Those are some tame ones.
title: Not for kids - at all.

author: chonest
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 28, 2020
review_content: Numerous INAPPROPRIATE cards, not kid friendly and not very creative to rely so much on potty humor and sexual innuendo in a family game. It also came in a different box than pictured. It was an industrial corrugated cardboard box, rather than a typical board game box. Not a huge deal, but not as pictured, not gift-worthy, and annoying since I didn't get to choose the different quality box. I returned it for a refund. Apples to Apples Junior or Loaded Questions Junior would be much better picks, lots of laughs for the whole family.
title: Numerous INAPPROPRIATE cards, came not as pictured, in a different box

author: Joni Miller
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2020
review_content: Not age appropriate. I was very disappointed in the first handful of cards I read, as I got this game to play with the whole family. The first few cards have things that my son would get in trouble for saying in school. :(
title: Not For Kids

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2019
review_content: Fun for kids and family. I removed around 15 cards from the deck that I felt were too inappropriate for kids. Like genitalia and boob jokes.
title: Fun game

author: nichole
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 28, 2020
review_content: this game sucks, basically threw 30 bucks in the trash. the "fill in the blank" statements are simple phrases kids already know, but the only thing we can do is turn them into fart jokes because all everyone has are cards about poop and fart. "twinkle twinkle little ______"....ok, but my card says "brown turd", my kids says "poop" and my other kids says "poo"....at which point, that's really not very funny or clever, nor can we really choose a winner because we are all saying especially the same thing.what made the game playable? taking the black cards from the original cards against humanity and using the kids cards to fill in the blank.much better,less cringey. however, that essentially means we paid $60 to play a kid friendly version of cards against humanity.worth it? maybe.
title: use these with cards against humanity

author: Katherine Pettit
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2018
review_content: My daughter and I had a blast playing this.
title: Fun!

author: Rachael
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 28, 2019
review_content: A really fun game to play with my 6 and 9 year olds. They love it! As a warning, it is raunchy, with lots of potty humor. There are some adult, sexual-in-nature references that are luckily lost on my kids (and sometimes me!). The humor can be appreciated on many different levels. I think it is best played with over 4 people and a combination of different ages works great. It is more difficult to play with non-readers.
title: Very Fun

author: JEN BRADFORD
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2019
review_content: Cute game, preteens had a blast
title: Recommend for tweens and early teens

author: Daisy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2020
review_content: We bought this before Cards Against Humanity came out with a family edition. We are huge fans of that game and hoped this would be equivalent fun we could include the kids. As described, most of the cards are silly potty humor, and we all get a good laugh out of it.However, there are quite a few cards that seem a bit to mature for even my kids (girl/boy, 11/12). Let me be clear, I am not a wholesome sheltering mother. I mostly speak to my kids like small adults. We are fine with some vulgarity, we even welcome it for the most part.But I was kind of put off by some of the cards which were not as kid-friendly as I had hoped. I do not like explaining why "Richard Johnson" and "One twig and two berries" are funny or what "Purple nurple", "dog's lipstick" or "fromunda cheese" are even to my tweens. Potty humor is fine for 8+, but d*ck humor seems more like for 14+.That being said, the vast majority of the cards are fine, but maybe you should screen them before playing with younger kids.
title: Mostly ok, but some cards not suitable for 8+

author: Niki
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2019
review_content: Definitely didn't think they'd just use titles of books or movies and add a blank for the other players to answer. No creativity. My 8 and 13 year old were disappointed.
title: Don't waste the money

author: Brandy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2020
review_content: My husband and I love these kinds of games. We love cards against humanity, what do you meme, rotten apples, etc. and play them every chance we get. My son, who is 9, absolutely loves card games and always wants to play. We play apples to apples, but he has a stellar sense of sarcasm, so the apples to apples just isn‚Äôt as much fun. I also love to include my mom, who excels at sarcasm but is far to religious for the adult versions. This is the perfect all around family game. The content is relevant and while it is super appropriate for kids, it can be a bit racy for the adults that understand the innuendos. We play it so much that we are already looking for an expansion pack for new content. We‚Äôre all absolutely addicted!
title: Outstanding Family Game for families who love to laugh!

author: Sarah Vickers
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2020
review_content: My kids and I play lots of similar games (they‚Äôre 11 and 13), after reading reviews and purchasing this, we were very disappointed. Waste of money for us.
title: Would NOT recommend

author: Lesesp
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2020
review_content: We love Cards Against Humanity in this house (for the adults, not kids) so I was hopeful this would be fun for the kids. We were not disappointed. The kids have a blast with this! Lots of potty humor (poop, fart jokes, etc...). If you are an uptight parent make sure you go through and read the cards BEFOREHAND and take out anything you don't approve of. I'm mildly liberal so I figured I didn't need to. After our first time playing, though, I realized I should have and went through all of them and I removed about 15-20 cards.  Mostly because I didn't feel like explaining what they meant. I would still buy this again! Really, the majority of the cards were fine. Easy play, no set up (other than passing out and shuffling cards), play until you want to stop.Edited to add-I read a bunch of reviews of people saying they bought it and trashed it and giving it low stars because it's not "appropriate". Not the sellers fault you didn't read the crapload of reviews that said don't buy if you're uptight, and that there is potty humor and some over the line jokes.
title: SO MUCH FUN!!-Don't complain if you didn't read the reviews first!

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2019
review_content: I was super excited to get this as my husband and I thought that this would be a hit with our 9 and 7 yr olds.  It was awesome and we laughed so hard my kid nearly pee'd his pants but some of the cards were definitely not appropriate.  When my 9 yr old wanted to know why "Mr. Richard Johnson" was funny we realized we needed to go through the deck.  They should up the minimum age.
title: Probably great for teens be cautious for younger kids.

author: McRichardson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2019
review_content: We have played this game about eight times since we bought it and love it. Played with mostly 8-11 year olds which seems to be the perfect age. There are a bit on slang type words that we actually had to look up. Fun for both kids and adults due to some innuendos. I can‚Äôt say it has a ton of replay-ability though. Once you‚Äôve seen some of the cards they kind of lose their hilarity. I could actually see mixing in some of the less crass Cards Against Humanity to liven it back up.
title: Lots of Fun

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2019
review_content: I had really high hopes for this game. I had to take quite a few of the cards out that weren't appropriate for my 8 year old and even then, he still wasn't interested. We are going to hold onto it and try again in a couple months. Maybe better for the tween age range.
title: It's just ok

author: HappyShopper
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2020
review_content: We love Cards against humanity and similar decks for adults. This was completely inappropriate cards for this age range. I‚Äôm thankful I sorted through the cards before allowing kids at a bbq to play it. We threw away 1/4 to 1/2 of the deck and the remaining weren‚Äôt entertaining enough to make the game fun for anyone. We were very disappointed.
title: Not Recommend for suggested age range

author: HEK
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2020
review_content: Got this for us to play with my 7 & 8 year old girls to give them a break from the strategy games that I prefer to play.  I taught the game to them in about a minute and we were soon laughing. Some of the cards are confusing to them (and us) and so they don't find them funny. It's interesting and fun trying to play cards that you think the kids will find funny versus another adult. I could see them not understanding why the adults picked some cards other than their obvious fart based ones but they didn't mind too much. I know we'll be playing it frequently enough but I'm not sure that the card quality justifies the price of the game given how much in involved is some other board games that I've bought for a similar price.
title: Fun, laughs but not perfect

author: anastasia
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2020
review_content: Wow!!! It says "educational" game...WOW!!! Never thought that thing like that can exist in children's game department. Once I got the card saying "front fart", I did not know how to react (my 9 y.o. KID was sitting next to me) and wasn't even sure what that is (hoping it is a kid sort of thing) but no, it was exactly what I hope it would not be. Sending it back ASAP and asking you to purchase educational games for any age children, but not the once developing stupidity and ignorance!P.S: if this is an Award winning game then I give up, no wonder this world is coming to an endü§Ø
title: Horrible "game"

author: Alexa Rose
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2020
review_content: It‚Äôs not so much the endless poop and pee and fart jokes that bother me, but it‚Äôs just really, really unimaginative. My kids like potty humor, sure, but when it‚Äôs the only thing going on, and when it‚Äôs paired with trite nursery rhyme prompts... it‚Äôs just not that fun or interesting. My kids are 6, 9 and 12 and they played a couple times before getting bored with it. The cards I took out were all sexual innuendos (Santa‚Äôs big fat sack?!) and jokes at fat or queer folks that don‚Äôt have a place in our house... Might be ok for some, but we were thoroughly unimpressed.
title: Unimpressed, boring

author: Backwoods Mister
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 30, 2020
review_content: I have 2 children, 11 and 5. I‚Äôm no prude. Hey these should only be marketed to teens, due to having to explain words like, ‚Äúdingleberry,‚Äù and some sexually-charged references that only adults will understand.While we‚Äôve had good fun playing, many of the phrases are too advanced for little people with little experience in such crass matters, so it‚Äôs hard for them to participate without some explanation. It‚Äôs basically a less vulgar version of Cards Against Humanity, and broaches ideas and actions that I‚Äôd prefer not to have to teach my kids in order to have Family Game night.With teens this would still be fairly awkward to play, but they would at least get most of the comical references. I would NOT however feel right about playing with the neighbors‚Äô kids because they would surely go home talking about butt crust and boobie holders.Don‚Äôt buy unless you have middle teens (15?) or you are prepared to teach sex-Ed and Advanced Toilet Humor for Kids 101. Otherwise this game is good fun with the right demographic.
title: Too Advanced/Crass/Dirty for Little Minds under 15

author: Ryno D. Bones
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2020
review_content: Cards are nice quality, and there are some very funny combinations to pick.  A lot like the adult game with a similar name, really.  Our teenager enjoys this, but it is not quite appropriate for our younger son...but close...manufacturer recommends ages 10+, and I agree.  Really fun game, though.  I can see us taking this on road trips, for sure.
title: Definitely follow the 10+ rating

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2020
review_content: We LOVED this game. My sister-in-law and I played with the kids and we were ROLLING laughing at some of the answers. Some of the cards were over the kids heads but made it funny for us! The kids that played with us were ages 8-14. Definitely worth it if you like cards against humanity and want something similar but not as gruesome for your kids. For those saying that it was too much ...they should buy the game apples to apples. This is definitely a step up from apples to apples for us and much more enjoyable! The kids were all dying laughing as well...especially when the answer had something to do with poop or farts! Definitely worth buying!
title: This game is GREAT!

author: Jason B Roth
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2018
review_content: Kids love the cards messages and so did my husband and I! I did have to take out a few inappropriate cards, overall though, not too bad.
title: Family fun

author: Nikki
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2020
review_content: Yikes! I don‚Äôt consider myself prude or uptight but for a family game...this is the stack of cards we had to remove from the game. I think there are other ways to be funny besides references to things like camel toes and moose knuckles...or Pickle Park (Google it, seriously not something I want to explain to my tween and her friends at a party). Also lots of wildly inappropriate racist references like ‚ÄúJackie Chan‚Äôs Chopstick Hands‚Äù. Also sooo many bathroom humor (ie poop, pee, and farting cards, like at least 2/3. Honestly there are other funny things. I‚Äôm confused how it won so many family approved awards.I love playing CAH, with adult friends ...so I get what they are trying to do here. Pushing the envelope is totally ok but for me, crossed the line with types of references they picked. In my opinion, totally missed the mark. As my 11 yr old daughter and I went through it, even she commented that there are so many more appropriate ways to be funny and laugh together, without using stereotypes or all that weird sexual stuff.I wish I would have researched better before shelling out $30
title: Not a family friendly game

author: CS
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2019
review_content: This game is so much fun and was easy to learn.  We played this with my 9, 7 and 5 year old grandsons  (We paired the 5 year old with an adult.) and we all had fun - kids and  adults alike!!!  Our son said the grandkids played it for much of their 4 hour car ride home and laughed the entire time. I highly recommend this game.  Great for family game night!
title: Fun game for all ages - easy to learn!!!

author: Mel2281
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2020
review_content: Ok so this game is a little racy depending on what your kids have heard however my son is 8 almost 9 and the potty humor cards drew the biggest belly laughs ever my husband and I made some inappropriate sentences but they went right over our sons head as he is a little sheltered rightfully so as he is only 8 but we all had so much fun my son did not want to stop playing and asks us to play all the time so yes I‚Äôd recommend as a gift only if you‚Äôve explained it may get a bit racy at times depending on the age to the parent but for us it was hysterical and a ton of fun
title: Belly laughs galore

author: John
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2020
review_content: I bought this for my kids, they absolutely love this game. I would expect a little higher age rating as some cards are really inappropriate for younger kids. (the listing say say fun for all ages) My family and friends are avid C.A.H. players and we have played this game more lately and have played it more than the kids have. There is a ton of butt and poop cards which my boys find hilarious though.On a more serious note, this is a really fun way to get your kids to practice reading and use their imaginations. They are practicing sounding out words, learning the meaning of others and they don't even realize it.I would definitely recommend this for other families. I would just caution that the age be more towards teenagers.
title: This game is amazing!

author: Cassandra
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 21, 2018
review_content: Not enough action cards. But it was fun to play at our game night with the kids. Lots of fart and poop jokes.
title: Funny kids game

author: (Charles) Kent McKenzie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2019
review_content: We purchased this as a holiday gift for our daughter, and the whole family enjoyed gathering around the table for several rounds shortly after it was opened. We like that the answer cards include humor that can make younger children laugh without being totally inappropriate, yet some of the subconscious thoughts from adults are even funnier. Easy-to-read and understand rules printed inside the box lid is a fantastic feature - makes it much more unlikely that we will ever lose the rules! Sturdy cardstock, clean and crisp printing - definitely a great game to have around when nobody can decide what to play!
title: Hilarious game that works for kids of all ages!

author: chattyone2
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2020
review_content: OMGoodness this is a hilarious game!  It's very easy to play, much the same format as Apples to Apples, if you're familiar with that game. No boring rules to learn, just open the box and play. We played this with various ages and had a great time.  I am 53, my son is 23 and my niece and her husband are 30 with a 10 year old son.  The innuendos went over the 10-year-old's head (perfect!) but there was enough fart and poop humor to keep him, and us, giggling. If you're uptight this is probably not the game for you.  If you don't like wind-breaking humor you might want to 'pass' on this game.  But if you want to laugh your butt off with the family this is a must-have addition to your game night rotation. Laughter is a great stress reliever.
title: Laughed ourselves silly!

author: Elizabeth
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 20, 2020
review_content: My husband and I love playing Cards Against Humanity with friends, and over the quarantine our 11 year old son came to love Apples to Apples, so I bought this to give us some variety in our daily game play.  The game is very fun and we have enjoyed playing, but some of the cards made me a little uncomfortable playing with my kid.  Most are just the normal poop and fart jokes, but there are a few that are rather more suggestive than most parents would like (My son is mature and we rarely censor things from him, but a few of these seemed weirdly sexual).  Some of the references were also outdated and things most kids, and even a lot of adults may not even get.  Buy the game, but read over the cards first to make sure you are comfortable hearing your child read them out loud.  There are more than enough innocuous ones for you to remove the few you may not be okay with.
title: Fun game, but read over the cards first

author: L.M. Cuthbertson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2019
review_content: So, this says it‚Äôs for age 8 and up.It‚Äôs essentially a ‚ÄúkidZbop‚Äù version of cards against humanity.  There are some questionable cards (‚Äúdoggie stylist‚Äù ‚Äúcamel toenail‚Äù) but generally would go over the head of younger kids.Not something I would recommend if you get offended easily and super shield your kids, but we were playing with my almost 8 year old, 11 year old, and my 16 and 18 year old siblings. There was definitely a difference in what different age players were reading into the cards meaning.
title: Fun, but questionable taste

author: Caroline R. Mckeown
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 20, 2020
review_content: This is cards against humanity for kids, well sort of. I saw all the other reviews and the cards they pulled as inappropriate and decided to order this game anyway because I don't find those things inappropriate for my kids. However there were other cards that I was not ready to explain (to my 9 year old, the game is completely fine for my 13 year old). "Sword fighting" and "My dog's lipstick" in particular were not things I was ready to explain to my 9 year old. But, that said, we had a blast playing this game as a family and I recommend it, just pre-screen the cards first.
title: Age-appropriate is at your discretion

author: Joan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2019
review_content: We had a birthday during Thanksgiving weekend and this is one of the gifts I purchased for my 11 year old great nephew.  The kids opened it and played and laughed for hours.  It is full of silly puns and at times over the top and on the edge innuendo.  It is funny, gross and silly.  The kids all over 11 years old loved it and played for hours, while the adults played spades.  No technology in the hands of anyone all evening!  The laughter was worth the price of this game.  My other great nieces and nephews all asked for their own game for Christmas!  Great purchase and a lot of fun.
title: Great purchase and the kids loved it!

author: Benkai
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 5, 2020
review_content: Do you have a young person at home who absolutely loses it when they hear the words vomit, poop or fart? If so, this is the game for you! This is not for those who are uncomfortable with body functions or those who are super competitive because winning is subjective.  You also can't take yourself too seriously if you really want to enjoy the game. Relatively quick, never takes more than half an hour for four players and it passes pretty quickly with lots of laughs. Be prepared though, to explain what exactly Chewbacca's dingle berries are.
title: May be inappropriate, definitely fun

author: VWatson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2020
review_content: We absolutely love this game, the kids ask to play it regularly since we bought it. I'll happily take the extra family time, since we have puberty to look forward to in the near future, when asking to play card games with us will be a thing of the past lol I have 3 boys (12, 10, & 7), and the goofy, gross sense of humor of this game has them rolling! I've even gotten sore ribs from laughing so hard! The box and cards are also pretty sturdy, it's already become a staple in our family game night. Definitely recommend!
title: Hilarious excuse for more family time

author: Kevkilp
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 18, 2019
review_content: Kids love it. Sure created a ton of laughs.  Also created a few weird moments... like when I had to explain to my son what a tramp stamp was.  Be ready for some toilet humor - probably good for 10 and up.
title: Some great laughs

author: Taunya
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2019
review_content: My teenagers love this game! Makes a great family night game. Will be buying the expansion pack.
title: Fun game night!

author: Jen Tyes
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2020
review_content: Let me tell you that my kids had so much fun with this game. My daughter is 10 and my son is 6. My husband and I love Cards Against Humanity and so when I saw this, I had to purchase. The starter pack contains a wide range of questions and answers. My six year old had no trouble picking up on the rules‚Äî he won the first round! There were some mildly inappropriate answers but they were above my kids heads and I reserved those for my husband when it was his turn to ask a question. So all in all, we had so much fun!! Lots of laughs and red faces!!!!
title: So much family fun!

author: Krystel Rinaman
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2020
review_content: My son bought this with birthday money and I approved it because it won some awards that made me believe it would be fine for the family. The warning label on the box made me believe it might have some scatalogical humor, but it was far worse than that. I‚Äôve had to remove lots of cards because they make me very uncomfortable. Younger kids wouldn‚Äôt get the jokes, but that‚Äôs not the point‚Äî I don‚Äôt want to introduce them to these terms, and some things are not things I want to joke about ever. With those cards removed it‚Äôs a fun game.
title: Remove cards!!!!!

author: Itsme
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 24, 2020
review_content: Playing with 2, 40 year olds, a 10 year old, and a 6 year old.They did a great job of pushing right to the edge of appropriate.  My kids laughed hysterically at a lot of the cards but some of the references or terms were a little outdated and while not ‚Äútoo adult‚Äù they just weren‚Äôt terms that have been used since I was a kid.In any case, this was a ton of fun for 2-3 games before we started getting repeat cards.  Certain cards became ‚Äúautomatic winners‚Äù and the game lost its appeal.Definitely fun for a bit but not something you can play over-and-over again in an evening.Side note:  There‚Äôs a narrow  window where getting putting 2 cards together is funny sandwiched between the cards being too childish and just laughing at funny words. I‚Äôd say 8-12 or so.
title: Fun but replay-ability is lacking.

author: Jenny
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 19, 2020
review_content: I'm a HUGE fan of cards against humanity, so I was super excited for a similar game to play with my kids.  It is great reading practice in a fun way.  That being said, strict parents may not think it is very kid appropriate,  but those parents probably wouldn't think cards against humanity is fun.
title: Great quarantine family fun!

author: M H.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2020
review_content: I went through the cards and pulled ones my younger grandchildren wouldn‚Äôt understand.  Then I pulled ones I thought might be a little risqu√© for my pre-teen grandkids and had their parents okay them.  They took out one they wouldn‚Äôt get and I didn‚Äôt want to explain, and we sat at the table to play.  They all LOVED it.  The ages playing were 7, 9, 10-1/2, 12, 58 and 61.  If their parents wouldn‚Äôt have had other plans (this was New Year‚Äôs weekend), they could have played for a few more hours.  Lots of laughter & good times.
title: Fun for All Ages

author: CS
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2020
review_content: I bought this for my daughter‚Äôs 11th birthday thinking it was more of. ‚ÄúGame‚Äù we could play...like kids and adults, hence kids against maturity. It‚Äôs not really a game. It‚Äôs more of an ad-lib. You pick a blue card at random then  white card at random and they go together to form silly statements. May be fun for little kids like 7 yrs and younger. Our daughter wasn‚Äôt interested and neither are we. We‚Äôll be returning...just not for our 11 year old. Thanks anyway!
title: Not what we expected

author: stormy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2020
review_content: We have an 8yr old and before we let her play this, we went through all of the cards and removed anything we thought would be inappropriate (and there really weren't that many!) We played when the grandparents came to visit and it was the most fun we've had during a game night! We played for at least 3 hours. Lots of laughter. I love that there is a kids version because we play Cards Against Humanity a lot and now our daughter can safely join the fun too!
title: The most fun your whole family will have on game night!

author: Alli H
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 21, 2020
review_content: Both my sister and I purchased this game for my 12-year-old son's birthday. It was so much fun, he kept both (and took one to his dad's). We bring it to most family functions these days, and almost everyone participates, including grandparents - we come from a long line of silly-folk. Clearly, this will not be for everyone, because it is full of "inappropriate" humor, and it has sparked a few conversations I didn't expect, lol, but it is so much fun to laugh with tween kids, and that's not always easy to do!
title: Hilarious

author: WorkerBee
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2019
review_content: This game is very quick to learn and has a fun concept. One player reads aloud one full-in-the-blank sentence. Then all the other players look through their hand to choose one word or phrase card to complete the reader‚Äôs sentence. Then the reader reviews all the players‚Äô choices, and rewards the one that the reader thinks is funniest.Some of the answer cards contain references to body parts that are a bit vulgar and unnecessary such as ‚Äúnards‚Äù and ‚Äúbutt lover‚Äù.  Others are funny/ok for kids such as ‚Äúhorse‚Äôs patoot‚Äù or ‚Äúmayor of tinkle town‚Äù. Also, it might be funnier to just have players make up their own endings free form. Because of the unnecessary vulgarity and the  need to have at least 3 players, I‚Äôd give this game a three.
title: Ok but too many butt jokes

author: breanne
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2020
review_content: Im so beyond happy i decided  to buy this! First and foremost my 11 year old came out of her room and off her conputer! She and her other 2 siblings were cracking up the whole time! Us parents too. We had a blast. The entire family wasnt reay to end the game. It was helpful to my learning readers and my oldest who has problems reading outloud. We will absolutely be playing this often! It has some jokes that are a bit on the naughty side and if you cant handle it you can take thoes out. For our home we intend  to enjoy and laugh at every single card! I would 100 times over reccomend this. Especially if you have a pre teen who gets absorbed into video games and need a fun way to unglue them from a screen.
title: Great buy!

author: L. Beach
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2020
review_content: The game started out pretty strong, but after about 30 minutes, we noticed several of the "answer" cards were not very funny on their own, so the chance of them being a humorous conclusion to a phrase was low. Near the end my sister started cheating because of the poor answer cards. She would look for replacement cards in the deck that were  the funniest. I didn't think there was anything inappropriate for children--lots of poop and fart references, but everybody poops--but some parents may disagree. My favorite answer card, and the one my daughter and I still laugh about two monhts later: "Mayor McCheese's Cheese Tongue." Heh.
title: Lots of Bathroom Humor, Some Answer Cards Are Duds

author: EVe
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 30, 2020
review_content: The age says 8+, HOWEVER... there were many cards that my 9 year old nephew did not understand or should he understand. Bad gift choice on my part. Really more like an easy drinking game for adults
title: Definitely not age appropriate

author: Christopher Ripley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2020
review_content: I was disappointed in this game. Our family had fun playing but it was not age appropriate for my 8 year old daughter. You need to go through the cards and take out the ones you dont want to have to explain, for instance ones that reference genitals. Also well over 60% of the cards are some form of poop or bathroom joke. Not very creative after awhile.
title: Its OK. Too many poop jokes. Not appropriate for my daughter

author: Stefanie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2019
review_content: There are way more question cards than answers. I thought this was just more answers but it‚Äôs both :(
title: Not worth it

author: Jennifer M.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 2, 2020
review_content: This is a fun game to play as a group. I have an 11yo girl and 5yo boy. They both thought it was really funny as did their much older uncles and cousins. Easy to pick up and game play can go on as long (or as short) as you want.  NOTE: fully 1/4 of the answer cards are poop or gas jokes (the stack on the right in the pic) and there may be other cards your family will object to as well.  Even after removing any you may judge to be a poor fit for your family, there are still PLENTY of funny cards to play with.  I deducted one star for lack of creativity in answer variety ( i.e. many bodily function answers).  Gift with note of caution to parents.
title: Prescreening entertainment is always wise

author: NC Mom of 2
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2020
review_content: We have played this game with my kids, nieces and nephews and it is a favorite of all the kids. On whether or not it is age appropriate, well, depends on you. There were definitely more uncomfortable moments for the parents rather than the kids. Point was that they UNDERSTOOD the jokes and the parents were thinking it was inappropriate. We've had a lot of great laughs, and quite a few inside jokes for a long time to come. It's a great game, but it is not for anyone that might be uptight.
title: Need to have a sense of humor!

author: LMKB
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2020
review_content: This is only appropriate for kids after throwing about 15 cards out. Subtle suggestive ones about private parts and sex. Example- Mr Merkins wig (pubic hair), Mr Richard Johnson (male part), Front Wedgie (female body part humor) etc. I had to look several cards up to even know what they meant. I don‚Äôt want my kids to know slang and crude phrases.After removing those my kids played and LOVED. Laughed non stop. Great family game for all ages who can read and up. Again, remove suggestive cards first.If you are queasy with poop, fart, diarrhea, and vomit humor this is not the game for you.
title: Hilarious. Appropriate after throwing some cards out

author: Viola Smith
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2020
review_content: Did not realize this contained much material with scatalogical humor and some with sexual overtones. That being said if that content does not offend you the people we played with enjoyed the game (adults and 11and thirteen year olds). The game was not properly described and should not be given to young people without being screened by parents so they can decide if they are ok with the content.
title: Not for everyone! Buyer beware.

author: Christine McGrath
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2019
review_content: My 15 year old was reluctant to play the game saying she‚Äôs too old for kid games. But we had a party and she  opened it and the laughing was non-stop! The kids couldn‚Äôt stop talking about the game at the end of the night!! It was a hit!
title: Great game for teens!

author: Leslie Truver
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2019
review_content: We've played as a family--parents, 12 y.o. and 10 y.o.--and everyone enjoyed playing. My 10 y.o. found it funnier than the 12 y.o. but I think playing with  friends instead of parents might be more fun for both kids. Highly recommend for this age group! Some of the cards are close enough to risque that kids find them daring, but they're definitely much tamer than Cards Against Humanity. This is like an edited-for-TV version of CAH.
title: Bought for my 12 year old's birthday

author: Anonymous User
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 17, 2020
review_content: I have a 17 yr old and an 11 year old and we play this together. We haven‚Äôt nelly laughed like that, together, for a while! Some of the humor may be a little risqu√© for some if you are embarrassed explaining things to your kids. We are a very open and can be very silly group so this is right up our alley. I only put 3 stars for giftable because I would only gift this to people that I was sure would not be offended by the humor. Sooo Much Fun!
title: Sense of Humor a Must

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2020
review_content: We play games together as a family (11 youngest child and 15 oldest child) all the time.  This games was contrived and boring.  I feel like I wasted money by buying it.  It is a poor version of Apples to Apples though I feel there intent was to be a cleaner version of Cards Against Humanity.  Wish I never bought it.  Was meant to entertain us during COVID, what a fail.
title: Dumb Game

author: Krissy Meek
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 13, 2020
review_content: We got this game for our family during the shelter-in-place here in California. My boys, (9 and 6) thought the cards were hilarious, and my husband and I did too, but there were quite a few that were not appropriate for the ages of our kids. While the boys didn't understand the worst ones anyway, I didn't like that they might want to know what certain cards meant. Maybe when they're older?Anyway, there's lots of fart and poop jokes, so right in a growing boy's wheelhouse. You'll definitely laugh when you play this - but if your kids are too young you might cringe a bit too.
title: Very funny - but lots of the cards are inappropriate!

author: Crystal V
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2020
review_content: This is basically apples to apples for kids but funnier. You have to have a sense of humor and be OK with some crude potty humor for kids to like this. My whole family loved it and my kids are 11 and 13 years old. We could play this for hours and never get tired of laughing. A few of the cards might fly over the kids heads but the adults will see the naughty humor in them. If you Have a problem with that sort of thing then you might want to sort through the cards when you get them LOL.
title: Kids and adults both LOVE this game!

author: My2girls
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2020
review_content: Our teenage daughters have heard us talk about playing cards against humanity. But we have told them there is NO way we will play it with them. This is where Kids against Maturity came in. The Toilet humor in this game is universal with Kids as well as Adults. Who does not snicker or laugh out loud at fart jokes! Some of the white cards even bring in Pop Culture. We had a 2 hr. flight this past holiday to FL and our girls asked to play it on the plane. So we brought down the trays and started to play. The flight attendant saw us playing and asked what it was. When we told him he started to laugh and said he would have to look into it. Needless to say we gifted it twice it was that good. It will honestly be my go to gift for families when we send something!!
title: Great replacement for when your kids are asking about playing Cards Against Humanity

author: JJJ
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2019
review_content: Fun game
title: Good buy

author: Tonna
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 5, 2020
review_content: I have a 16 year old and 2 13 year olds. My husband, kids and I played this game and had a blast! Yes some things turn out gross like boogers or bathroom things, but at home is the best place to laugh and have fun with this kind of stuff! We really do enjoy playing this game as a family. It plays just like apples to apples which we play the original version and the disney version (apples to apples).
title: Family time must!

author: Zeha
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 13, 2020
review_content: Not going to lie, I'm that mom that is overly protective and was hesitant but decided to go with it. My kids vary from elementary age to high school age. We took this on our camping vacation and it really ended up being one of the best nights. Yes, there are things that adults will get that the youngest wouldn't and that made it even funnier. I would recommend this game to any of my fellow parents.
title: Hours of Laughter for All Ages

author: J Green
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2019
review_content: My kids really enjoy this game. They ask me to play all the time, usurping  the TV which makes this Mama happy. Is there potty humor? Yes, but they do that anyway.  Makes me happy to hear them laugh and interact together instead of arguing or zoning out to electronics.
title: Makes the kids ignore the TV

author: JDW
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2020
review_content: This game is great for kids and adults. Sure, some of the "answers" are gross (warning - if you are really against "potty talk" then you might look elsewhere) and some are head scratchers for kids and/or adults. Interestingly, the answers that parents don't understand often are not the same as those the kids don't understand. I would call it perfectly appropriate for ages 8+ with some questions at the younger ages (I'm on the conservative side though). Part of the fun is hearing the grandparents read some of the answers aloud.It's fun to play as a family game and a good/inexpensive gift.
title: Hilarious "Family" Game

author: Bakersfield Grandma
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2020
review_content: We like to play card games during dinner sometimes, and this was perfect!  As for age appropriate, three generations are having so much fun I am pretty sure it would be great for any occasion or age group.  This would be perfect for rainy day, kids parties, grownup parties, family get togethers, and it really created a lot of laughs and happy communication for our family.
title: So Much Fun

author: Tamika
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2020
review_content: My older kids were frowning at first but ended up having THE MOST fun playing. We all can play together and everyone has a ball without having to worry about mature content or swear words, like some other games we have and play censored - or without the adolescents. Seriously hilarious good clean fun.I'll be buying this for other families as a gift for sure.
title: Way More Fun Than Expected! Good for Family - ALL Ages.

author: Tess
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2019
review_content: I just recieve this in the mail today. Packaged well. My kids and I immediately started playing right after unboxing. All the question cards and Answer cards are all decent and good humored. This is the kid friendly version of the Adult version "cards against humanity."
title: Kid friendly and funny

author: Sandra R. Buckmaster
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2019
review_content: My granddaughters loved it
title: Fun game

author: pharmgirl81
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2019
review_content: Our favorite game for family game night! So many laughs
title: The Best!

author: A. Vreeland
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2020
review_content: The reviews for this game really led me astray.  Per reviews I had expected this to be fun for all ages so me and other adults played it but this game is definitely meant for 8-12 year olds.  No younger because they need to be able to read well and no older because the fart jokes and references are for kids.  Not even tweens.  They are childish jokes my seven year old son would find hilarious.  I honestly enjoy fart jokes and so does everyone in my family but jeez they got old quick.  I just don't get the reviews that say adults enjoyed this game.  We had a couple of giggles but mostly just groans.  And we went through a ton of the cards in one game so if we did like the game we wouldn't be able to play it much before we'd be seeing repeats.
title: Not for adults, definitely geared towards kids

author: Bonnie Jones
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2020
review_content: My grand kids loved it. Wasn't sure my 7 year old granddaughter would understand the humor but she got it and played a little better than her 9 yr old brother! Lol! Us adults went through the cards the night b4 we introduced it to the kids and pulled out a few that were a little over their heads or posed situations that we weren't ready to explain at their ages. üòâ But there are SO MANY cards/questions, we didn't feel like it affected the game or our fun time at all. I rated only 3 stars for "giftable" because as the description explains, I would leave it up to the parents to decide if it's appropriate for their kids.
title: Highly recommend!

author: stephanie young
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 13, 2019
review_content: We love this game! I read some reviews saying that this game is not appropriate for kids. I have to disagree. I thought the game was fine for my 9 and 5 year olds. They loved it and they didn‚Äôt get the jokes that some would think we‚Äôre inappropriate, anyway.  If you think the underlying innuendos are too much for the little ones, you could always remove the cards that you find inappropriate, until you think they‚Äôre old enough to handle it. The game is really fun for the whole family. It‚Äôs highly recommended by ours!
title: So fun!

author: Schaedee
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2020
review_content: NOT a family game. Farting and bathroom jokes I can deal with ‚Äî it‚Äôs what children find funny til the develop a more refined sense of humor. But answers like ‚ÄúMerkin wig‚Äù ?  No no no. How do I explain that to a child??  Or worse have an inquisitive 8 year old who looks it up??
title: Not appropriate for family

author: Jack
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2019
review_content: Wow! Love love love! I have 3 teenage kids and my 12 year old received this game as a birthday gift. This is literally the best family card game ever! We can't stop, won't stop playing, can't stop won't stop laughing! This was my kids best gift ever - we literally don't get bored playing it. Highly recommend as a unique Christmas gift cuz it's appropriate for kids of all ages. Also, the cards are strong and durable, not to mention portable! Thank you, kids against maturity- we haven't laughed so much together as a family in a long while!

author: Phyllis  macfarland
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 19, 2020
review_content: This is a fun game. Age appropriate and adults will like it as well. We played with multi generations (grandparents , kids, grandkids) and we had a blast. Bought to have the game at grammies house for when the grands come, but have also play with the adult children without kids and they loved it also. This would make a great gift also.

author: Lisa G
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2019
review_content: We have enjoyed playing this game as a family. I have had to explain some of the terms and jokes to my kid so for some people it might be embarassing. Also some parents of younger children might not be as appreciative of some of the humor, however you can remove some of the cards you aren't prepared to discuss.Either way, we have had a blast with and glad we bought the game

author: patty4fern
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 17, 2020
review_content: We sent the game to our daughter and family (3 little girls 3, 6, & 10), here‚Äôs their response: Super funny! Hubby had 3 yo granddaughter  repeat the words on the card when it was her turn to be judge and it was absolutely hilarious! It‚Äôs funny cuz there are some that are adult humor but the kids don‚Äôt get it. So it‚Äôs fun for all. It would be fun at the next family reunion Campout.
title: Fun for all ages!

author: Working Mom 3567
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 22, 2019
review_content: Super fun concept. Jokes on the box itself were funny. Explaining to my 9 year old what a camel toe or moose knuckle are???? Not cool. Many jokes are too mature. Be prepared to explain what everything means. If you don't want to, don't play.
title: Too immature for some kids

author: David E.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 7, 2020
review_content: Kids against maturity, as the name suggests, is a kids version of Cards Against Humanity. I have an 8yo who loves this game. After playing it a few times, I realized how great the cards are as an adult version. You will not be disappointed. There are a lot of poop and fart jokes so if you are sensitive to those, this game is probably not for you. This game works well for younger kids like mine, but I'd imagine teenagers would get a hoot out of it as well.
title: Awesome game for Kids, even better for adults

author: Danielle McDonough
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 24, 2020
review_content: Half the deck had a peeling or chipping film on the cards. If you scratched them at all it just started flaking right off.Also, completely inappropriate for the lower end of the age range stated. We ended up having to take out so much of the deck it wasn‚Äôt even fun to play anymore. We love cards against humanity and we have better luck playing that with our kids than this unfortunately.Overall a super cheap quality and tacky game that still costs a good amount of money.  I would not recommend this to anyone.
title: Cheap quality cards and overall tacky game!

author: Crystal
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2020
review_content: Every Holiday my family has a get-together, we currently have  12 kids under the age of 11 and typically the kids will occupy themselves with video games and tablets while the adults play card games but I wanted to be able to include the kids so I bought this... BEST DECISION EVER! The kids were ecstatic when I told them they could join us for game night. It was fairly easy to explain they all understood it quickly. There are a couple of kids that can‚Äôt read but we just had those kids team up with someone who could read the card to them. These cards contain everything that kids these days find hilarious. This is a new family favorite!
title: Family Favorite!

author: Teresadnhb
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2019
review_content: What a fun family game night!
title: Love!

author: Jeremy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2019
review_content: Very cool game! It's very hilarious and fun for the whole family!
title: Awesome!

author: M. Ryder
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2020
review_content: Wish you could let your kids play "Cards against Humanity" but aren't interested in completing corrupting them, and getting dirty stares from the other parents when their kids are corrupted by your kids...?Ease your conscience by buying this version - easy to learn, fun to play, and perhaps the only thing you'll have to explain is "dingle-berries."

author: akl-krl
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2020
review_content: Not for overprotective parents. If you play cards against humanity you understand the game. These cards are only slightly raunchy... Many have different meaning for the kids and adults so the game is fun for all ages. If you are okay with your kids laughing at fart jokes it is great.  I told my kid if she didn't understand a card I wasn't going to explain it and she could just draw a different card, and I went through ahead of time and pulled out a dozen or so cards that I didn't feel were age appropriate.

author: Sarah N.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2019
review_content: This game is so much fun! It's the perfect alternative to Cards Against Humanity for 10 and up.  There is some borderline comments that may not be appropriate for younger kids (moose knuckles and weiner references) but we played with a 4 and 8 yr old and they just didnt get those references. author: laceyloo92584
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 1, 2020
review_content: The hubs and I love Cards Against Humanity so when I saw this was like a kids version of it, I was sold! My kids ages are 9 (b/g twins) & 17. They all 3 loved it! title: SO much fun for the WHOLE family!!!

author: Too Busy to Go to Store Mom
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2020
review_content: Not sure what the age range was on this, while the cards were all kid-appropriate, there were a few that had double meanings of adult humor.  I was playing with teens so it was perfect.  I felt much better playing this game with my kids than playing cards against humanity with them.  I would play this again, We will play this again and had much fun.  This would be a great game to play with a mixed crowd of adults as well.  We had moments of laughter that paused the game.  A total win!

author: Tina Marie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2020
review_content: We bought this particularly for a family camping trip.  It is portable and so easy to learn, with no extraneous pieces and nothing else needed, so that is great! We were all laughing hysterically...and about 1/2 hr. in, the novelty wore off and we were bored of it.  I hope that is just us, because I really love everything about it, except that it didn't hold our interest very long!

author: R. Glick
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2020
review_content: Omg.  I laughed until I couldn‚Äôt breathe.  Ya know how when you are card shopping and that FUNNIEST EVER CARD hits you in just the right way and you start laughing like a total freak, with tears running down your face, and you nearly start convulsing?  Well.....that‚Äôs what happened while playing this game as a family tonight.  HILARIOUS!
title: Sooooooooo freaking funny!

author: ArmyWife
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 15, 2020
review_content: This isn‚Äôt really an 8+ game.  I bought it for my teen daughter and her friends.  I took a few out that I thought might not be ok but they still found ways to make it inappropriate.  Example:  My favorite after school snack...your mom.  They are teenagers so I know that isn‚Äôt terrible but I wouldn‚Äôt want my 8yo playing it.

author: Crista
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 1, 2020
review_content: LOVE this game! Similar to Cards against Humanity and Apples to Apples in style. SO easy to learn. My 5 year old plays. If you can read you can play. Games go quickly making multiple rounds easy or a quick round no problem. It‚Äôs HILARIOUS. A bit raunchy at times. Not for prim and proper folk. Many fart and poop references. Keeps us laughing! Package is a nice thick sturdy box too. Well done!
title: Buy! It‚Äôs hilarious and EASY!

author: McChelisa
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2019
review_content: This is SUCH a fun game. We‚Äôve been long time fans of Cards Against Humanity, but obviously can‚Äôt play with our 9-year-old. Enter Kids Against Maturity. We played this afternoon and everyone laughed REALLY hard. Some things were a little risqu√©, but they went over our kiddo‚Äôs head. Highly, highly recommend if you have a weird sense of humor and have passed that on to someone waaay too young to play an adult game.
title: So much fun

author: Autumn
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2019
review_content: This game is great for entertaining. Our family loves to play with just us, but its simple enough the kids can play without any adults with their friends. Very funny and a great substitute for Cards Against Humanity for those that don't want such an adult game.
title: The family LOVES this game!

author: Jennifer Detlefsen
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2020
review_content: I‚Äôm kicking myself for not listening to the reviews that caution on this one. Many cards are beyond innuendo. Kids are naturally curious and mine asked straight up, ‚Äúwhat does this mean?‚Äù My husband and I kept asking how this was a game intended for kids. Our youngest is ten but even our 17 year old got a bit of an education that she didn‚Äôt want. If you rely on urban dictionary in many circumstances, stay away from this one and keep your babes away from it.
title: NOT For Kids.

author: Sara W.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 26, 2020
review_content: I don‚Äôt consider myself over-protective or prudish by any means, but this game is not appropriate for anyone under the age of at least 13. Cards like ‚ÄúSanta‚Äôs fat sack‚Äù ‚Äúmoobs‚Äù ‚ÄúChewbacca‚Äôs dingleberries‚Äù are funny, and my kids were laughing their butts off, but now I have to worry about them repeating these phrases. It‚Äôs probably a really funny game, but I‚Äôm definitely putting in the closet to save for several years down the road.

author: Julia
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 30, 2020
review_content: My 10 year old loves this. I would say it's probably not appropriate for much younger than 10 - but the jokes are definitely funny to adults. author: JPocket
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2019
review_content: My husband and I love the 'cards against humanity' game so much that when I seen this one, I just had to get it for my family. author: Meagan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2020
review_content: My kids love this game! And it was fun for the adults playing as well. One of my sons is still working on reading outloud more fluently (he has autism and doesn't like to read aloud) and this game made him want to read. Would definitely recommend. Lots of giggles from the kids the whole time we were playing.

author: Working Mamamamama
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2019
review_content: Have this to my 13 year old for Christmas and our family played it last night  (parents and 13 and 8 year old girls). It is hilarious! Parents, if you enjoy Cards Against Humanity, this is a great family alternative. Lots of poop and fart references. Nothing sexual that we ran across. I don‚Äôt think the 4 of us have laughed so hard together in ages. If you are okay with being a little ‚Äúinappropriate‚Äù and silly and are careful about not playing with people who are offended by bathroom humor, it‚Äôs a great time.

author: RogueA138
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2020
review_content: Tried to play this with my 11 yr old and her 12 & 13 yr old cousins. It didn't go well. there are alot of sentence filler cards that have pop-culture references that were not just unfamiliar to the kids but to me and my brother (both mid 30 yr olds). Each sentence card only has one blank space unlike "Cards Against Humanity" which sometimes allows you to play two space filler cards to make it funnier. A lot of the time wa spent just playing cards to get rid of them whether it made sense or was funny at all in the hopes that the replacement card would be better. What Do You Meme game was better than this one.

author: Liz MacAlpine
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2020
review_content: My kids are 10 & 12, and not only did they not find it funny, they themselves said it was ‚Äúinappropriate‚Äù, and I totally agree! author: Momma Miles
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2020
review_content: I'm a mom that loves boardgames. My 10 year old loves gaming. Decided to gift this first for immediate use at son's quarantine birthday bash. He was so angry. The family lasted 4 rounds & the birthday boy had a blast. Great find. Make the children socialize!- Cool 40 year old mom

author: John Lawrence
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2019

review_content: My kids are loving this game.  It‚Äôs exactly like Cards Against Humanity but scaled back for a younger audience.We have a 9yr old boy and 7 yes old girl. It‚Äôs a safe step to take just to be sure.

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2020

author: Christine Stewart
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2020
review_content: Hilarious game for big families, family groups, or group of kids. A lot of the cards relate to potty humor which made all of my kids and their friends laugh hysterically. The kids didn‚Äôt want to play at first, but I bet them a full size candy bar, of their choice, that they wouldn‚Äôt make it through the game without laughing. Needless to say, after the first two rounds, all 9 kids lost the bet!!

author: KFlurry

review_content: This is a good game. The only trouble is that my kids are 12 & 8 and the 12 year old feels the content is just slightly too young for him. Otherwise I‚Äôd give this 5 stars as it is really easy to learn and play. We grab it right after dinner and it keeps us all together enjoying each other‚Äôs company before the magnetic force of electronics is felt by the kids.

author: Karen Dulaney
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2020
review_content: My husband, myself and 2 kids, (preteen and teenager) played this. We laughed so hard and really enjoyed this game. My dad's expressions were hilarious when he's reading the cards given to him. My boy was getting pissed b/c my dad kept picking my card - I told him he has to play a card he thinks "pop pops" would pick, then he started beating me. LOL.
