date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2019
review_content: The only funny card is ‚ÄúMr. Richard Johnson,‚Äù which, while admittedly hilarious, is not worth $25.
title: Great for families with no sense of humor

author: RDemeule
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2020
review_content: The night started out great, the giggles began, the laughter continued, we were having a blast, And then all of a sudden the kids continued laughing, but my wife and I locked eyes uncomfortably realizing what had just occurred in front of us. Many people have stated that the cards included in this set go over the heads of the kids, however, it is important to realize that they will remember these words and you are teaching them to them. All one needs to simply do is load the Urban dictionary and type in a few of the answers that are provided for this game, in doing so you will be appalled at the depravity that the publishers of this game are putting in the hands of children. One reviewer stated they removed one or two cards, I went and removed at least 50. I'm almost embarrassed to list a few of the terms that are on the cards, however, you need to see for yourself. My wife played a card called Mr merkins wig, my children played a card called Pickle Park and Mexican Mudslide, another called dog's lipstick, and yet another one called bat wings and camel toenail. Take some time and look them up for yourself.  If we hadn't already opened and played the game I would have returned it immediately. My children are 9 and 12, we have a good time, we laugh a lot, but a game of dirty innuendo plus butt and poop terms is not our intention of great evening. I am highly disappointed in this game.
title: Not appropriate for many children, buyer beware

author: Joe Jackson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2020
review_content: I read a few bad reviews and assumed that people were being up tight,  but they were right. There are way too many dumb poop cards. There are a lot of cards that kids don't understand and you don't know whether you should explain this to your kids because it's not appropriate. For example, camel toes. We the game a few tries but didn't care for it much. It went in the trash.
title: Not ideal for kids

author: Tina Watkins
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2020
review_content: This is NOT a family game! Before I bought this, I looked at the reviews - specifically looking to see how bad the cards were! I purchased this expecting an overabundance of potty humor. I was right. I purchased this, figuring I could remove the worst of the potty humor. I was right (1/4 of the deck). HOWEVER, I did NOT expect the raunchy sexual humor - not for kids!!!!! Going through the deck, I found NUMEROUS cards with filthy sexual things such as "dirt button", "missle toe" (yes, spelled exactly like that), and "moose knuckle" just to name a few. Look these up to see what they actually mean if you don't know! I'm returning this and hoping my review will help others who simply wanted a fun/slightly disgusting game for the whole family to play!
title: NOT for kids/families - ADULTS ONLY!

author: K.S.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2020
review_content: Let me start by saying I have played Cards Against Humanity and had good laughs. However, the options on this deck are TERRIBLE for kids and families! It is ALL bathroom humor, and much of it inappropriate (I couldn‚Äôt even weed out the bad ones from the good because it was pretty much all of them) . My boys are 13 & 11... we ended up throwing it away because I couldn‚Äôt stomach giving it away - it‚Äôs really awful. How there are so many highly rated reviews blows my mind - please read all the one star reviews prior to purchasing.The price is also way too high for a simple deck of cards.Buy ‚ÄúNot Parent Approved‚Äù instead - same concept, but actually funny and much more family-appropriate.
title: So bad that we threw it away!

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2019
review_content: My partner and I are fans of Cards Against Humanity and knew that this would be a blast to play with our kids who always want to play but clearly the answer is a big no on that. We played with my children who are 11 and 13 and we laughed all night. Now, we aren't people who are afraid of humor or sex jokes. When we pulled a card that read "Mom's cooking tastes like ________." And my son put down "Santa's big fat sack" the day after Christmas we all just about died but this would likely be super inappropriate for a vast majority of families.It was a great way to bond with the kids as they transition to this newer age and it breaks the barriers of sex talk without directing it at them. Although I'm our house it's not necessary because we aren't afraid to joke around with our children.I will not be allowing my kids to play this with friends, not without a full on explanation to their parents first and permission at least.I think it will also be fun to add to Cards Against Humanity or to add the mild cards from CAH to play this with the kids.Parents who shy away from sex and poop and such, this is not the game for you. This is not a game to play with other people's kids without permission and it's definitely not appropriate for school or any other formal setting.I'd say the age rating is more appropriate for older kids. My youngest is 6 and had no idea why we were laughing.
title: Totally inappropriate but also hilarious

author: Stasi
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2020
review_content: A while back I created a PG-13 Cards Against Humanity deck to play with my kids (by pulling out the most inappropriate cards). We've had a blast playing it, but it's limited, so I thought this would be a good supplement.Unfortunately, this just isn't a very fun version of the game. Now, we enjoy a good poop or penis joke as much as any preteen boy, but they make up the vast majority of the cards, so that even my 10 year old son was getting bored with it. (My 12 year old daughter thought it was completely stupid -- it's just not clever.) Many of the double entendres would offend some players...we just found them obvious.There are also many cards that reference old toys, situations, or people, and my kids have no idea what they are. We had to pull many cards out just because they were meaningless to us.Honestly I would recommend just making your own deck out of CAH cards instead. You can pick better cards and don't have to roll your eyes at the dumb ones.Finally, I took off a star because Amazon sent me a used game. The cards were dirty and one was even ripped.
title: It's just not very fun

author: H. Lindsay
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2020
review_content: This card game is more for adults who enjoy potty humor and sexual innuendos than for kids. I thought this would be a fun game for my kids who like poop jokes but I was shocked to find so much sexual slang in it. And then I read that they have that in for parents to enjoy while playing with their kids, like the kids won't repeat it when with their friends or at school unaware that they will be using crass sexual innuendo? Really? And I'm a parent who just doesn't have humor? There is no way this should be a game labeled for children. Not even Disney movies with their adult humor thrown in would stoop to this level.
title: Horribly inappropriate for children

author: Steve R.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2018
review_content: We played it all Thanksgiving break with my kids (10,15 and 16) my mom and neighbor's sooooo much fun!! Huge laughs and everyone had a blast!!
title: Better than Aplles to Apples!!

author: TheColes4
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2020
review_content: I saw the great reviews for this game and decided to give it a try. I regret it. We are a conservative family with morals and values and a lot of the cards are SO inapropiate for children. A lot of potty talk, most of the cards talk about poop or toilet language, vulgarity...and other phrases like "Stop____or you will go blind", "the creepy ___ uncle" or "mom's purple wine teeth" etc.Just made our kids ask questions that we couldn't answer as we didn't want them to know these things and dirty up their minds.
title: Not a clean game.

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2020
review_content: The description states that only over-hovering people that don't like "flatulence jokes" won't like this game. I was so excited to get this game and play it with my family (nephews/niece ages 7-16). However, there were too many penis jokes, sexually explicit items. 20 years ago, this would have been find, because how could a 12 year old find out what that term meant? But I don't really want to be playing with my family and have my nephew say "Hey Google, what's a Turd Burglar?" And have us all listen to how it is a derogatory term for a homosexual (not the only one). This game had so much potential, but I don't need my young, impressionable family members using these terms because they think they are funny, only to realize as they get older, that the term is referring to rape, weird sex acts, and/or pedophilia. I wish there was more of a warning...I don't need my 7 year old niece asking Alexa what a "Smurf village" is, because it sounds cute and she wants one for Christmas. FYI: my picture shows stacks of cards: the far right are cards I've deemed too inappropriate to play with people, the middle stack is fine for adult friends, but not my young nephews, and the left-hand stack are ones I still need to look up on Urban dictionary. I just couldn't look up any more last night...I feel like I need to wash my brain.
title: Not suitable for children - take out some cards first!

author: Dwight L Barnes
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2019
review_content: This game is so creative with its double entendres, unique word play, a plethora of idioms, weird names, nostalgic movie and culture references, hilarious questions, and all staying in the bounds of 7-18 year old range. The combinations of phrases that are created creates such of a dynamic of an immature atmosphere to make you get that kid feeling of ^recess^ humor. They blended so much humor to cross over ages and the way we think as we grow. This game has those kinda jokes that your kid will grow up be like 29 years old an call you cause they just realized they just got what the joke "really meant" and why you were laughing so hard at that game. It is genius so much so we use the game to teach{ESL} English as a Second Lamguage in foreign countries, the phrases, questions, quotes, idioms and culture introduces so many different aspects of speech from the funny names to the fill in the blank questions are great just by themselves and are fun for conversation practice. It was good cause it was all based off humor and curiosity. I read the reviews one lady didn't even buy it and gave a bad review.smh. See we know some people might not get what some of the cards mean we just removed the from the deck. Until later when it will make sense to them but the beauty of the game or you and your kid can both be laughing but at two different meanings. Phenomenal game with multiple layers of humor.
title: Double entendres, idioms, word play, nostalgia

author: Margie Kaufman
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2018
review_content: Been waiting for the 2nd edition. Love this game! My kids (6, 9 & 15) love playing Kids Angainst Maturity with their friends. It's the one game that gets them off their phones!
title: Great family game!!

author: A. Thomas
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2020
review_content: Our family loves games so I thought this would be great with so many amazing reviews.. I did read one that suggested going through the cards and removing ones that may be inappropriate and did so before even showing the game to my children (9 & 11).  I‚Äôm SOOO glad I did!!! Im shocked that parents would think this is even slightly appropriate.  Yes I know kids love potty humor and that‚Äôs not where the biggest problem is (although I find potty humor lazy and unimaginative), what I found most disturbing were the sexual references, vulgar terms (ex camel toe & turd burglar).  It went on and on... I had a pile of about 10 cards to toss out and after seeing the endless poop references I decided to return it!  I do NOT need my children learning derogatory terms that would get them kicked out of their school for repeating from a ‚Äúfamily/kids‚Äù game!  Shame on the makers of this game... seriously.
title: No no no!!!! Not for kids!!!

author: Christine B
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2020
review_content: My just-about-12 year old has been begging us to play Cards Against Humanity, but that is way, way, way, way too inappropriate for her and we always have to say no.  I was so thrilled to get this for her for her birthday so we can play as a family. We laughed until we cried. They didn't get some of the jokes, and we explained a couple of things as we went (like what 'pinching a loaf' is) and some of them we didn't explain at all and moved on and they are none the wiser. That said, yes, it's poop and fart jokes, which we find hilarious.  If you don't like potty humor, you probably won't like this game, but we had a great time as a family and our 12-year old had a chance to show off her skill at matching her answer cards to the questions.  Glad we found it and can't wait to play it again!

author: MICHALE M
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2020
review_content: This is a game is supposed to be targeted towards kids but with cards like "Wolfman's nards", "moobs", and "Nutella on my chin", I did not want to continue playing with the kids. I laughed hard several times, but it was all inappropriate card pairings that thankfully the kids didn't understand."Nutella on my chin"? Come on, I know exactly what that is supposed to mean. Ages 6+ this game IS NOT.Pizzagate.
title: Ehhh.....

author: J. Ryjewski
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2020
review_content: The kids love playing this game and it was easy to teach and play with the grandparents over Christmas. Though some of the innuendo on some of the cards is over their heads, we have decided to remove a few cards. I wouldn't feel comfortable gifting this to friends without a word of caution to the parents to read through the cards first to make sure the humor is appropriate for their family. Cards we removed: moobs, mom's purple wine teeth, banana hammock, one twig and two berries, back boobs, workman's nerds, pinching a loaf, a manhole cover, a hole, all hail the sofa king!, my cat's starfish, my dog's lipstick, Aunt Flo, chafed nippers, pumpkin bottom jeans, wacky tobacco, fartknockers, front wedgies, front farts, camel toenail, Bangkok, alien probing, creepy uncles, lady and the tramp stamp, boobs, Kim kardashian's booty.

author: Cameron H.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2020
review_content: Since I play cards against humanity and the kids always want to play and its to adult for them. I saw this and I thought it would be fun. My son is 13 and they start understanding things more around that age. How ever some of the cards together are just as bad as cards against humanity and there are cards with characters in there before their time. It says ages 8 plus but I wouldn't give it for a kid. I am barley comfortable playing it with my teen.

author: sara lincoln
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2020
review_content: My niece and nephew are five years old and seven years old. Though it‚Äôs not exactly age appropriate we still got it and still played it with them. 2020 has been such an ugly year I genuinely didn‚Äôt mind the the kids asking what a dingleberry is. They laughed so hard these cards are full of potty humor. They needed the good laugh. If you‚Äôre super sensitive and like to shelter your kids this is NOT the game for you and your family. If you don‚Äôt mind a few innuendos going over their head and potty humor get this one! It‚Äôs hysterical.
title: Might have to explain the word dingleberry

author: Sam Brown
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2020
review_content: My husband and two boys 11 & 13 years and myself love this game.  We have played it several times since Christmas. It‚Äôs great not to have to set up a board and pieces.  We can sit around the living room or wherever.  Every games has lots of laughs when you put the cards together.  I‚Äôve played the adult game (cards against humanity) and loved it so when I saw one for kids I clicked purchase right away.  I have already brought the refill.  I highly recommend this game for you family game nights.
title: Definitely a game to laugh during playing. Great family fun

author: xinex29
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 11, 2020
review_content: So many laughs with this game!!! My only ‚Äúcomplaint‚Äù is that I think it‚Äôs more appropriate for ages 12+. I guess I should have read through all the cards before playing but I just assumed with the rating, the phrases would be more about poop, boogers and farts, and not so much tramp stamps, twig and berries and nards. My eight and ten year old learned some new words and phrases for sure. We‚Äôll just make sure to go through the rest of the deck before we play it again because with that said, it‚Äôs still a keeper.

author: Sarah Helton
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2020
review_content: Christmas gift for my 10 year old. He found it so hilarious. A few cards were a little mature for my liking so I just removed them. He is too young to get why I thought they were worth removing but I felt better after. Aside from looking at the cards first it is an amazing game. My son laughed so hard I was concerned he might stop breathing lol. We enjoyed watching his laughter.

author: Alixandra Simon
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2020
review_content: This game says for 8 and up.. it should say 16 and up. I felt like we should have just played cards against humanity because that‚Äôs how vulgar some of these cards are. My 20 yr old brother had to google what mr merkins wig was, it‚Äôs wigs for your genitals.. I got the card dirt button, I‚Äôll attach its meaning so you can see how not appropriate it is. I think if you play and don‚Äôt know what some of these are you maybe wouldn‚Äôt assume it‚Äôs bad, but if you look up some of these things up it‚Äôs definitely not a game for anyone under 15-16. Us adults that played with the two kids (12 and 7) loved it!! They need to change the recommended age for sure.
title: Not for under age 15-16

author: Katana
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2020
review_content: My son is 10 years old, has a wonderfully witty sense of humor and we love this game! Quarantine nearly got the best of me and I stumbled upon this card game just in time. I pulled a couple of cards out that I thought were a bit too mature, n.b.d... I haven't given myself a whole lot of time to play since I grew up once I returned from Neverland and I nearly forgot the hilarity of farts, hemorrhoids and diarrhea! I'm eternally grateful for the bonding and belching memories that have blossomed thanks to this game of flatulent family fun. Cheers and thanks go to the creators of this game...it may have saved my sanity! I've also realized that I truly am a 10 year old at fart--I mean HEART! A 10 year old at HEART! üßö‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüòùüëç
title: Flatulent Family Fun! üí®

author: Katie of the high hills
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2020
review_content: So my dear elderly mother bought this for my kindergartener. She was so excited that it had won all sorts of parenting awards and family game accolades. My son can read very well and was promised poop jokes, so he was up for it.First round:Lying makes your ______ grow biggerMy dear six year old played:Dirt buttonI‚Äôm rolling laughing at the marketing pictures for this. I love the elementary school birthday party that will soon learn about ‚ÄúJackie Chan‚Äôs chopstick hands‚Äù (wow!). I‚Äôm also very into the picture of the three generation family awarding the win to the tiny girl who probably just played ‚ÄúSanta‚Äôs big fat sack!‚ÄùI‚Äôd give it more stars if they‚Äôd picked an audience. Are you going for 6-13 potty humor? Or high school sex jokes?I can‚Äôt believe this won parenting awards. I‚Äôm chortling to myself. Two stars only because I will always remember this afternoon.
title: Jaw-droppingly inappropriate for kids. Try teens.

author: Voloviaus
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2020
review_content: We will definitely be buying the expansion packs. My teens and 9 y/o all got in on this fun game when family came to town.  It was non-stop hilarity, and it's close enough to Cards Against Humanity but not agree appropriate, although there are still some innuendos.  I'd recommend to anyone who doesn't take themselves too seriously and can laugh at poo and fart humor.  Maybe the expansion packs will add different subjects.  Looking forward to finding out!

author: Alice Tyner
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 18, 2019
review_content: I just got the product yesterday My daughter wanted me to get it as a gift for my grandsons7 years to 10 years old So I cannot review this product I cannot give any stars

author: Baker
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2020
review_content: INAPPROPRIATE FOR KIDS! I love playing cards against humanity with my friends and thought this would be a fun and slightly similar game to play with kids, ages 10 and 11. author: lance
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2020
review_content: I bought this set as a gift for my niece. I‚Äôm glad I read the reviews and went through the cards to ‚Äúfilter‚Äù it so that it was age appropriate. If your getting this game for a teenager, I guess it wouldn‚Äôt be too bad but since my niece is only 9, filtering out some of the cards was needed. There are some cards in this game that 100% have double meanings to them that at face value, would probably go over a child‚Äôs head but as an adult, you can certainly pick up on the darker meaning of these cards... just be careful when gifting this and if you are unsure, do what I did and filter through them. 98% of the cards are perfectly safe and appropriate for young kids which will make for a very fun and great game night!

author: Ashley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 23, 2020
review_content: OMG, this was my best random Amazon Daily Deal purchase to date. I bought it randomly to take up to the mountains for a long weekend. I'm going to purchase about 5 more boxes to get out as birthday presents because the people I hang out with are funny and would appreciate it. It's an actual game that adults and kids can play together and have the best time nobody's going to get bored.

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2020

author: Mom to 4
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 4, 2020
review_content: I played last night for the first time with my children, ages 8, 10, and 12. While the cards went entirely over their heads, these were among the phrases in our one game. author: Belle's Book Labyrinth
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2019
review_content: My kids, nieces and nephews LOVE this game! We have family game night once a week where about 15 of us will get together to play board games and card games. date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2020

The balance of humor in the game made it very unenjoyable I would not recommend it to anyone. I really don't understand how it supposedly won all these awards.

author: Amee Johnson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2020

But it‚Äôs a game that had a brief moment of fame in our house and is now banished to gather dust on a shelf.

author: Dave
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2020

author: RoRa1313

author: Austin Pasquarette
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2020
review_content: So they judge you right in the description calling people hoverparents when really they just have morals... this is no where near age appropriate and should not even be allowed on Amazon. author: CH

author: bes

author: Sasha

author: Melface
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 6, 2020

author: Macy Cook

author: Ms. Mouse

author: SommMom

author: momma
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 25, 2020

author: Alex W
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2020

author: Jdf1234

author: Jaime
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2020
review_content: We like to play games when the extended family comes to town.  We've found that playing games relieves some family tension.  The twenty something age kids like to play Cards Against Humanity but I have young teens and the grandma is there so we found this game to be a perfect compromise.

author: Primer

author: roomia
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 10, 2020
review_content: In my house of boys, this is a family favorite game. The cards are printed on good quality paper. The categories are great the cards are amusing. Lots of laughs. There are some cards that  are a bit inappropriate, so you might want to skim thru them.

author: Dora
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2020
review_content: The kids loved it! They laughed so good. They ended up getting all the neighbor kids over to play for an hour. It‚Äôs fun until you‚Äôve heard them all. Also side note: too many poop cards, alien related, some odd ball cards that I tossed aside cause didn‚Äôt want my kids exposed to them. So parents please go through the cards and read them yourself alone, so you can take out the ones you don‚Äôt feel are appropriate for your child/ren.
title: Kids loved it!

author: Michele
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2019
review_content: I read the reviews on this game before I purchased so I was fully aware that some of the cards may not be "appropriate" for specific ages. We played this at Thanksgiving with my brothers, mom and my daughter (11) and niece (13). So I went through the deck before hand and removed some of the cards I didn't want to have to explain or turn red over. lol Honestly, they were not that bad for their age group; the younger kids didn't end up playing so those cards could have been fine. Anyways, we all had a great time and had a lot of laughs. Exactly what I was looking for with a game. A more PG version of Cards Against Humanity that I could play with my family and not blush over or have to steer clear of future family events lol I could see us playing it again at future get-togethers. Would recommend.
title: You won't regret buying it....

author: nnleroux
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2019
review_content: Okay this is a awful parenting confession...I bought this game for my kids because they hear us laughing and in hysterics when we 'adults' play the other 'against' card game. The game came in and honestly curiosity got the best of us. We opened the box and played it, "just to see". I have to say, I think this 'against' game is funnier than the other one. My husband and I were laughing and just having a great time with our answers! I'm so happy we got this for the "kids". I have a feeling the adults will like this game just as much and now our children can join us. Fabulous game and a must for any family looking for a great laugh! Now to put the box back together so they don't know we opened it.
title: Awesome family game

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2020

Lol We still absolutely love this game and play a lot. It‚Äôs definitely worth getting.

The cards I removed included a "fat shaming" reference (to give you an example of what I felt shouldn't be included)! The card that referenced "a-hole" was another I removed.  It's a GREAT game, though!  Lots of fun!

author: Jason
date_of_review: Reviewed in Canada on June 15, 2020
review_content: In our household, we have been playing Cards against Humanity, for quite a while now. More than once my son has asked to play, and for obvious reasons, has not been allowed.During these super fun times of being quarantined in the house, I've been looking for ways to keep him entertained without resorting to tv and video games. When this popped up on a lightning deal I figured why not give it a shot. To sum it all up, I don't think I've seen him laugh so hard playing any game ever. There were moments when he was laughing so hard he couldn't breathe and he's been asking to play it almost every night since I gave it to him.Now as a warning to some people. This game pretty much revolves around potty humor, so if you find yourself easily offended by this, or find no humor in it, I would highly suggest you take a hard pass on this game. However, to an 8-year-old boy, this pretty much hits them right in the funny bone.
title: An absolute hit with my son

author: Hannah
date_of_review: Reviewed in Canada on May 3, 2020
review_content: Not as funny as we thought it would be. My kids are 11 and 13 and both were not impressed. I would say this game is good for kids in grades 1-4, since the humour in the cards is something they would appreciate; playing on words such as ‚Äòbooby trap‚Äô. Definitely NOT something teens would enjoy, unless they grew up in a very sheltered environment. Great for young kids, but pass on it if your kids are in grade 5 or older.
title: Don‚Äôt buy if kids are 10 or older!

author: Teresa
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 3, 2020
review_content: I read mixed reviews and having played the adult version I'm no prude, however this game is highly inappropriate for children under 14.... "turd burglar" is not something I want my children 9 & 10 understanding. I was shocked that card was not in the adult game. I've gone through the pack and removed half the cards now. Personally I wish I hadn't brought it but my kids liked the the silly joke side, so stuck with it..my adult game has gained some card now though, so every cloud!
title: Homophobic and really not funny.

date_of_review: Reviewed in Canada on July 9, 2020

How do you explain "30 minute showers"? How is that to be funny for the kids... (that is the only that made us adult smile). The rest are poop references for the most part, or the questions just do t fit the whole round of answers. Boring unless adults are drinking  is my guess.
